description.narrative: Amref & Plan contributed to this indicator

title.narrative: # people reached (men & women & boys and girls) through serial discussion and campaign on FGM & CM and HTTP (disagregated by sex and age)

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Woredas: Bahirdar Zuirya and Qewete in Amhara Region). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1600 using a standard formula- taking into account possible ?design effects? because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. However- the political unrest impacted the administration of data collection- in Bahirdar Zuria nly 46% of the planned target- in Qewet it was possible to reach 100% target. This resulted in an overall coverage of 73% (1166 respondents) as compared to the planned target.

comment.narrative: Outcome indicators baseline data are assumed zero.

title.narrative: Enhanced dialogues among men & boys & girls & women on harmful impact of CM TP and FGM

description.narrative: Amref& Plan contributed to this indicator

title.narrative: # campaign conducted on harmful impact of CM & TP and FGM

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Woredas: Bahirdar Zuirya and Qewete in Amhara Region). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1600 using a standard formula- taking into account possible ?design effects? because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. However- the political unrest impacted the administration of data collection- in Bahirdar Zuria nly 46% of the planned target- in Qewet it was possible to reach 100% target. This resulted in an overall coverage of 73% (1166 respondents) as compared to the planned target.

comment.narrative: Outcome indicators baseline data are assumed zero.

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM

description.narrative: Amref- PLAN- DEC- TaYA contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of FGM and C

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of FGM and C.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all All gatekeepers know that FGM is illegal- but most are not correctly knowledgale about the harms of FGM.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all All gatekeepers know that FGM/C is illegal and are aware that FGM/C is harmful. However some are not clear on the health consequences of FGM/C and believe that uncircumsised women cannot give birth or have sex prevail.

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM

description.narrative: Amref- PLAN- DEC- TaYA contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of CM and TP

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of CM and TP

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Many gatekeepers have knowledge about the harms of child marriage. Also of TP but more so when this it out-of-wedlock.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all There is a general awareness about the harms of child marriage and teenage pregnancy among all gatekeepers including fathers mothers and religious and traditional leaders. While the harms of CM are known some also see at the same time benefits such as economic benefits or preventing pregnancy out of wedlock.

description.narrative: Amref- PLAN- DEC- TaYA contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent CM and TP (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. CM and TP.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all All gatekeepers expliclity express CM is prohibited for under 18 years of age. Some are actively involved in efforts to prevent it however others in their actions appear in contradition with their attitudes. Many gatekeepers view CM as a way to prevent TP.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all More gatekeepers have changed their attitudes towards CM and are raising awareness about the harms of child marriage including mothers and religious leaders. Teachers and a few community members are reporting CM cases to the authorities. The police and kebele officials are working to stop arranged CM.

title.narrative: Goal 1. Community members and gate-keepers have changed attitudes and take action to prevent CM FGM and C and TP.

description.narrative: Amref- PLAN- DEC- TaYA contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent FGM and C (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. FGM.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all All gatekeeprs expliclity express FGM is prohibited under the law. Most are actively involved in efforts to prevent it- however others- in their actions- appear in contradition with their attitudes.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The majority of the population is aware that FGM/C is prohibited under law. Health workers and teachers are working against the practice and are raising awareness. Most circumcisers have stopped the practice after participating in trainings on awareness raising and income generating alternatives.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls and boys have increased access to ASRHR information and services and child protection services

description.narrative: TaYA- DEC- PLAN contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in current access to SRHR information by girls and boys aged 15 to 24 years

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years. And focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Seems more girls than boys have access to SRHR information And- girls in rural areas have less access to SRHR information.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all All young people have access to SRHR information particulalry through schools health centers and NGOs. New peer to peer discussions in schools have started. New youth friendly health services also provide information and new manuals on SRHR (Meharabe) have improved youth access to SRHR information. There is a general discrepancy between in and out-of-school youth in access to SRHR information.

The Yes I do alliance and its partners have the knowledge and skills to implement gender transformative programmes
# of staff of implementing partners receiving GTA training

description.narrative: Data source: Progress report

comment.narrative: Outcome indicators baseline data are assumed zero.

title.narrative: Men and boys are successfully and actively engaged to reduce CM- TP and FGM and C
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C and CM and TP (disaggregated by CM FGM and C and TP)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C CM and TP is not commonly apparent in the community.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Males (particulalry young males) are aware and positive about the efforts to eliminate CM and FGM/C and reduce TP. Young men are actively engaged in new youth clubs (e.g. ECHO) that report child marriage cases and speak up about arranged CM. Young males also contribute to facilitate the use of contraceptives and thus preventing pregnancy. Males are less engaged in strategies to reduce FGM/C.
